title: 113_hr863
content:
The Act is titled the "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum Act." It defines terms like "Commission" and "Museum" and establishes the Commission for this purpose. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum is established with 8 members appointed by various leaders based on qualifications related to women's history, art, and culture. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum is looking for members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising, women's history, representation of women in art and culture, public service, museum administration, and museum facility planning. Federal employees are prohibited from serving on the Commission. The initial members must be appointed by a deadline. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Women's History Museum must appoint initial members within 90 days of the enactment of the Act. Vacancies will not affect the Commission's powers and will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson will be selected by majority vote of all members. SEC. 4. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to submit reports to the President and Congress regarding recommendations for establishing a National Women's History Museum in Washington, DC. The reports should address issues such as collection availability and cost, impact on regional women's history museums, potential locations in DC, and whether the Museum should be part of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission is tasked with developing a fundraising plan to support the establishment, operation, and maintenance of the National Women's History Museum through public contributions. Considerations include governance structure, engaging women in design, and cost analysis. Reports must be submitted within 18 months of the Commission's first meeting. The Commission is required to consider the role of the National Women's History Museum in fundraising for construction and funding operations without federal appropriations. An independent review of the plan's viability is also mandated. The Commission will submit a plan to fund the Museum without federal funds to relevant House and Senate committees. Legislation will be proposed based on recommendations in the report. The Commission will present a plan to establish the Museum to key House and Senate committees. A national conference may be convened within 18 months to discuss the Museum's advancement in women's life, art, history, and culture. The Commission will present a plan to establish the Museum to key House and Senate committees. A national conference may be convened within 18 months to discuss the Museum's advancement in women's life, art, history, and culture. SEC. 5. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Commission may employ an executive director and necessary personnel. Rates of pay must align with temporary organization standards. Employees are not considered Federal employees. Federal agencies can provide technical assistance upon request, but no Federal employees can be detailed. The Commission may employ an executive director and necessary personnel at rates of pay aligned with temporary organization standards. Federal agencies can provide technical assistance upon request, but no Federal employees may be detailed to the Commission. SEC. 6. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS.

Members of the Commission serve without pay and are not considered Federal employees. They are allowed travel expenses. The Commission can accept gifts to aid its work and is not subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act.

SEC. 7. TERMINATION. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting final reports. The Commission is responsible for funding and cannot use Federal funds.
